why: Fiscal Responsibility, Developmental Planning, Environmental Issues, and representation of all #HeightsResidents on BCC.#VotePurcell
work to limit city expansion boundaries?: There are definitely concerns over what could happen if there is unlimited expansion. The City of Billings must have the ability to provide municipal services to those areas that are annexed without creating an unnecessary financial or resource burden for those areas already within the city limits. Billings is expected to increase about 40,000 in population over the next 20 years. That’s with a 1.5 increase in population. Where that population will locate is important and careful planning to accommodate growth is important. Studies show that the millennials and baby boomers are the age groups for whom the city will need to provide services in the future. At the same time, it will be necessary to consider how we can continue to be a community that is attractive and thriving so as to cause young individuals and young families to be attracted to Billings. Undeveloped areas in the midst of us can be unattractive and an eyesore! We need to look to development of infill areas to the greatest extent possible for the benefit of all.
pass a fully inclusive non discriminatio: Of course we should pass a fully inclusive non-discrimination ordinance. How can we possibly claim to care about our City and its’ people when we know that discrimination exists, that individuals are hurt by that discrimination, yet we do nothing to stop it. I find it hard to believe that anyone wants a friend they care about or a family member to be discriminated against. Pass it.
expand jail diversification programs - i: Expanding jail diversification programs would be a good thing. The American Medical Association determined alcohol addiction to be a disease in 1956. Many people with addictions (drug and alcohol) require treatment of one kind or another in order to remain drug and alcohol free. There are those professionals who believe that methamphetamine is a harder addiction to break and that in-patient treatment is a must for some individuals in order for them to be successful. Most certainly, Drug Treatment Courts have been successful, in good part because those involved with Drug Treatment Courts know that they are being monitored, and that there is available to them a strong support system to help them remain drug and/or alcohol free. Helping people remain drug free is a far cheaper way to deal with the issue of addicted people than incarceration. People who are drug/alcohol free can become contributing members of society.
expand the multi-use trail and bike lane: Multi-use trails and bike lanes seem to be a very popular thing and I would think that wherever possible, expansion of those would be a good thing. At the time streets are being painted for traffic needs, it makes sense that if there is adequate space for bike lanes that the addition of those could naturally occur and would require little money to do so. Multi-use trails and bike lanes are used by a wide variety of different people and wherever they can be added and there is adequate funding to do so, it makes sense.

why: Billings’ future: a diverse, environmentally sustainable, well planned city, attracting talent to build community & jobs paying living wages
work to limit city expansion boundaries?: City boundaries must be managed in regards to the needs of the city now and in 20 years. Holding city boundaries is only part of the equation, planning to meet the needs of an aging city, with diverse housing needs, and growing demands on city services need equal consideration. Infill and population density plans are crucial. All of these must be considered in conjunction with increased demands on services.
pass a fully inclusive non discriminatio:
As the largest city in Montana we cannot afford to look to the past. 
Billings’ future is before us and it demands our attention. Our future is dependent upon enticing a diverse, talented work force, attractive to high tech businesses paying living wages, willing to invest in our shared future. By building a more diverse community, we attract high tech companies willing to engage the Montana work force stereotype, pay a living wage and ensure a motivated, innovative, and dedicated work force. To achieve this we must:
-        Continue to create an environmentally green city
-        Develop the city’s reputation as a diverse community
-        Ensure that all who live here have a voice 
-        Implement ‘out of the box’ ideas to conserve water and reduce or delay the need for a new water processing plant
-        Plan the city’s future foot print to include affordable housing
-        Provide more information to the voters on all issues before them to allow for informed decisions One of Billing’s strengths is its diversity which will continue to grow, our goal should be to ensure each citizen has an equal voice at the table, feels safe in their neighborhoods and has equal access to all city services.
expand jail diversification programs - i: Recent reports show the “Spare change for real change” Serial inebriate, downtown program is working. No less than 32 individuals have taken advantage of this program since inception. Evaluating who is serviced by the jail, costs of services to outside entities and future projections are being considered. The city is making recognizable progress in these areas.
expand the multi-use trail and bike lane: Already I see the new bike lanes in the Heights being utilized. Our trail system is expansive and growing. Use will only increase and will serve the future Billings resident wanting neighborhoods, with a diverse populations bringing diverse needs and businesses to serve the resident.
